artefact.overview: To provide early years childcare, register on the Home Childcarer Approval Scheme with your local Health and Social Care Trust (HSCT)
artefact.licence_short_description: To be a childminder and be paid to look after a child in their own home, you must register with your local Health and Social Care Trust (HSCT)
artefact.licence_overview:
$! If you want to become a registered child carer through the Home Childcarer Approval Scheme apply to your local Health and Social Care Trust (HSCT). $!

##Restrictions 

You must: 

+ be 18 or over
+ have a childcare qualification or have attended an induction course
+ have a relevant first-aid certificate
 
##How to apply

Send form HCC1 to [your local HSCT](http://www.nidirect.gov.uk/index/information-and-services/parents/childcare/types-of-childcare/home-childcarers/early-years-teams.htm "Contact your local HSCT office"){:rel="external"}.  

$D
[Download 'Form HCC1, application to become a childcarer' (PDF, 80KB)](http://www.nidirect.gov.uk/home_childcarer_application_form.pdf "Download 'Form HCC1, application to become a childcarer' (PDF 80KB)"){:rel="external"}

[Download 'Being a home childcarer' (PDF, 7MB)](http://www.nidirect.gov.uk/beingahomechildcarer.pdf "Download 'Being a home childcarer' (PDF, 7MB)"){:rel="external"}  
$D

##What happens next

The HSCT will make some checks, including a Criminal Records Bureau (CRB) check, and contact you to arrange an interview with a social worker. 

They'll write to you after your interview confirming your registration number. 

You must renew your registration every year.

% Usually, if you're not registered employers can't claim tax credits to help with the cost of the care you provide.% 

*[HSCT]: Health and Social Care Trust
*[CRB]: Criminal Records Bureau

authorities.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust

apply.introduction: This online application form is for those who wish to become a registered home carer in the Northern Health and Social Care Trust area.  A home carer is a person aged 18 years or over who cares for children (aged from birth to 17) in their own home, or for children of no more than two families, wholly or mainly at the home of one family at any one time.
